div.l: And se how gates the mele falles a doune
In till the trough that schall be my disporte
Qᵈuod Iohn in faath I may ben of your sorte
I is as ill a Miller as ere ye
This Miller smyled of here nycite
And thought all this nys don but for a wile
Thei wene that no man may them be gile
But be my thrifte yet schall I blere here ye
For all the sleight in here philosophye
The more queynte crekis crekis that thei make
The more will I stele whan I take
In stede of flour yet will I yeue hem brenne
The grettist clerkes ben nought the wisest mēnne
As whilom to the wolf thus spak the Mare
Of all here arte counte I nought a tare
¶ Out of the dore he goth full pryuely
Whan that he saugh his tyme softely
He loketh vp ⁊and doıı̄un till he hath foıı̄unde
The clerkes hors ther as it stode y y boıı̄unde
Be hynde the Mille vndir a leuesell
And to the hors he goth hym faire ⁊and well
He strepeth of the bridell right a noon
And whan the hors was loos he gynneth gon
Towarde the fen thare wilde Mares renne
And forth with wehe thorow thikke ⁊and thorow thenne
This Miller goth a gayn no worde he seide
But doth his note ⁊and with þese þe þese clerkes pleide
Till that here corn was faire ⁊and well groıı̄unde
And whan the mele is sakked ⁊and boıı̄unde
This Iohn goth out ⁊and fynt his hors a weie
And gan to crye harrow ⁊and welaweie
Our hors is lost Aleyn for goddis banes
Steppe on thi feet come of man all at anes
Allas our wardeyn has his palfreie lorn
This Aleyn all for gate bothe mele ⁊and corn
All was oute of his mynde his husbondrie
What whilke weie is he gon he gan to crie
The wif com lepyng inwarde at a ren
Sche seide allas your hors goth to the fen
With wilde mares as faste as he may go
Vnthank com on his honde that bonde hym so
And he that better schulde haue knyt the reyne
Allas ꝙquod Iohn Aleyn for cristes peyne
Ley doıı̄un thi swerde ⁊and I will myn alswa
I his his is full swift god wate as is a Ra
By goddis herte he sall nought scape vs bathe
Whi ne had thou put the caple in the lathe
